thread.title: Logano the toast of NASCAR once again
thread.title_full: Logano the toast of NASCAR once again

title: Logano the toast of NASCAR once again
text:
Report an error KANSAS CITY - 
A lot has changed since Joey Logano took the NASCAR Sprint Cup Series by storm in 2009, winning his first race in his first season as a raw 18-year-old driving the No. 20 Joe Gibbs Racing Toyota. 
He was given the nickname “Sliced Bread” as in the best thing since. 
Unfortunately for Logano, his career at JGR went pretty much downhill from there until he was rescued by Roger Penske and put behind the wheel of the No. 22 Team Penske Ford in 2013. 
Now Logano is again the toast of the stock car racing world after winning back-to-back races in this season’s Chase for the Sprint Cup Championship. 
Once considered a soft driver that competitors could push around on the race track, Logano has developed into a hardened pro as he showed on Sunday when he pushed Matt Kenseth — who ironically inherited the No. 20 Toyota — out of the way to win the Hollywood Casino 400 at Kansas Speedway. 
He has learned along the way that very often in NASCAR racing, nice guys do in fact finish last. 
At Kansas, however, he said he was not playing the part of the bully but was only doing whatever it took to win the race, something every other driver in the race would do in that situation. 
“We just happened to go in the same corner and we both went for the same piece of real estate,” was the way Logano described his getting to the back bumper of Kenseth’s car. “I wanted that middle lane and so did he, and we collided there ... it was hard racing. 
“He ran me hard and I ran him hard back ... that’s the type of driver I am and the type of racer I’m gonna be and it just comes to that point sometimes unfortunately those things happen.” 
Logano reached back into the history of stock car racing to justify his actions on the next to last lap at Kansas. 
“There’s a lot of aggression there and that’s what our sport is built on,” he said. “That’s what we do ... that’s what we do every week. We go out there and race each other.” 
Logano certainly wasn’t about to issue any apologies from wrecking Kenseth. 
“It’s a tough sport,” he said. “It’s like that in any professional sport. It’s not supposed to be easy. 
“It wouldn’t be that much fun if it was easy. We wouldn’t be doing this, so that’s why this is the top level of motorsports here in the Sprint Cup level. 
“It toughened me up pretty quick in the first two or three years of my career. You don’t really have an option sometimes but to toughen up.” 
And if you think that Logano is about to take his foot off of the gas pedal this week at Talladega Superspeedway with a free pass already in his pocket to the next Chase round, you would be wrong. 
He said he will not be doing any defensive driving at the big, bad Alabama oval 
“That’s our job is to go out there and win,” Logano said. “I’m pretty sure you look at some of our legends in our sport, they didn’t go out there to run second. 
“They didn’t become Hall of Famers by saying, ‘Second is good this week. We won last week.’ 
“We’re able to go into that race and be relaxed and that’s something to feel good about because our goal coming into this weekend was to win the race and keep everyone not feeling too comfortable about Talladega.” 
He goes forward in his quest for a first Sprint Cup championship knowing that his owner has his back regardless for what others may think of his driving. 
Penske said on Sunday all he does is give Logano the best car possible to start the race and the rest is up to him. 
And he doesn’t expect Logano’s recent tough driving style to change anytime soon. 
“He’s got to race the guys around him,” Penske said. “We don’t race the car. We prepare the car and bring it to the track. Each one of these drivers know what the circumstances are and with that they’re gonna make the moves that are necessary to try to get ahead. 
“To me, that’s gonna be the pattern as we go the next four or five races.” 
CANADIAN ‘STILL ALIVE’ IN CHASE 
Canada’s contribution to the Chase for the NASCAR Sprint Cup Championship took a hit at Kansas Speedway but is still alive. 
The No. 78 Furniture Row Chevrolet team of Martin Truex Jr. with London, Ont., native Cole Pearn running the show on pit lane started the day in third place, but fell to the eighth and final Chase position after a 15th place result in the Hollywood Casino 400. 
It was all because of stop and go penalty after an errant tire got away during a pit stop on Lap 213. 
Prior to the penalty Truex was running in the top-10 but after he made his pass-through penalty, he fell a lap down. 
“It was a tough day,” Truex said. “We fought hard on the car all day and got much better right when we got the penalty. We were fast at the end, but not enough time to get back up there.” 
The good news is that Truex is still in the thick of the playoff battle going into next week’s wild-card race at Talladega Superspeedway when only eight of the 12 drivers now in the Chase advancing to the next round. 
“We’re still alive,” Pearn said. “Considering what happened today I guess it could have been worse. We’re still on the plus side heading to Talladega.”
